column4: I'm pretty sure that your problem is not related to X configuration; it's that the nVidia kernel module isn't being loaded
However, I'm unable to test this, because when I rename my copy of the nVidia module (so it can't be loaded, to try to duplicate your problem) and reboot, something puts it back  :-/
You said earlier that your Driver line in xorg.conf says "nvidia", right?
no, I didn't
Does /usr/lib/xorg/modules/drivers/nvidia_drv.so exist?
Open a terminal and run "apt-cache show nvidia-glx" -- do you get any output?
When you "install nvidia", what exactly do you do?
Using nVidia's .run file is wrong on Ubuntu, and envy probably is too
On the System->Administration menu, choose "Hardware Drivers"
What do you see in that window?
OK, close that window for a moment
OK, you're encountering a bug that I found yesterday:  for some reason the package lists didn't get downloaded during installation, and the Hardware Drivers window doesn't work right without them
Fom that terminal window, run "sudo apt-get update", and when it's done, open the Hardware Drivers window again
I actually can't access the internet to download at this very moment but I will be able to later. Would it be all right if we spoke later about this when I am able to download?
I should be around, though I can't make any guarantees
but basically, once you do "apt-get update", the Hardware Drivers window should work correctly
In particular, the "enabled" checkbox will be unchecked, and when you check it, it'll install the necessary software and tell you to reboot
and then it should work  :-)
I'd expect that installing nvidia-glx through synaptic *should* work too, but the Hardware Drivers window is the "official" way to do it
and you may actually need nvidia-glx-new rather than plain nvidia-glx
to go with the "nvidia-new" kernel module that you saw mentioned earlier...  I'm not sure what the difference is though
